awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Field-Emission Scanning Electron Microscope to support multidisciplinary research and education at the University of Mississippi
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the acquisition of a state-of-the-art Field-Emission Scanning Electron Microscope (FESEM) at the University of Mississippi (UM). This instrument will impact a broad area of research projects, ranging from fundamental biology to nanomaterials and nanoscience.  The new microscope will enable ultra-high resolution imaging and analysis of a variety of materials including nanoparticles, nanocomposites, synthetic polymers, biological samples, metal platings and geological materials. The availability of this resource will directly benefit at least 25 research groups in 10 departments, spanning across the School of Pharmacy, School of Engineering and College of Liberal Arts. Additionally, the instrument will impact the research capabilities and training of many student researchers and postdoctoral associates in these research groups. The new instrument will support several academic courses and benefit hundreds of students in the science, technology and engineering fields each year. The new imaging facility will also benefit researchers from neighboring institutions, high school and community college students, and will greatly impact K-12 students and teachers through outreach activities involving the instrument.

The proposed instrument is a versatile microscope with high magnification and ultra-high spatial resolution, enabling high quality imaging and analysis of micro and nanostructures. This state-of-the-art instrument is equipped with multiple detectors, including energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer, cathodoluminescence, back-scattered electron, and secondary electron detectors to facilitate the determination of the elemental composition and topographical study of samples. The new equipment will be used across a number of cutting-edge research projects, including a) characterization of gold nanoparticles and investigation of their monodispersity, b) paleontological and biostratigraphic studies and quantitative reconstruction of paleoenvironments and paleoclimates, c) investigation of silica nanoparticles and nanocellulose in developing innovative and intelligent antimicrobial coatings for food packaging applications, d) study of Polyhedral Oligomeric Silsequioxane-functionalized graphene and polyurea nanocomposites, e) characterization and utilization of titanium dioxide/graphene oxide nanocomposites, and f) characterization of drug embedded nanoparticles and other matrices. The new microscope will also support numerous other research projects in various UM departments as well as neighboring institutions in the region.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF-MRI project (2017-2021) funded the acquisition of a Field-Emission Scanning Electron Microscope to support multidisciplinary research and education at the University of Mississippi (UM). A new state-of-the-art scanning electron microscope (SEM) was acquired, and an SEM Core imaging facility, Microscopy and Imaging Center, the only facility on UM campus for SEM imaging and analysis, was established. Since its beginning in July 2019, the core facility has provided various imaging and training services to the UM research community.

The SEM Core has supported several cutting-edge research projects, from fundamental biological studies to the development and analysis of nanoparticles. During the project period, nearly a hundred individual users belonging to twenty-five research groups in twelve UM departments have directly benefitted from the Core services. Equipped with multiple detectors and advanced features, the new microscope enabled imaging and analysis of more than seven-hundred samples. These samples represented various material types and included biological tissues, fossils, geological materials, polymers, microplastics, gunshot residue samples and nanomaterials. The results obtained from the new microscope during 2020-2021 have supported more than thirty research publications, including peer-reviewed research papers published in high-impact journals, conference presentations, grant applications, undergraduate and graduate dissertations and Ph.D. theses.

The SEM has been incorporated into three courses and supported over fifty graduate and undergraduate students. Fourteen users have benefited from the in-depth one-on-one training and gained knowledge and hands-on experience on the SEM operation and sample preparation techniques. A video demonstration was also developed for virtual learning during the covid-19 pandemic.

A new webpage dedicated to the SEM Core has been developed and published online (https://pharmacy.olemiss.edu/mic/) . The webpage has information on the instrument, user fee, reservation, policies, funding source and contact details. It also includes an image gallery and lists of research publications utilizing results from the microscope. The Core web page is regularly updated, poster presentations are made, and webinars are presented to disseminate information about the services offered by the SEM Core to communities within and outside UM.

The successful management of the SEM Core and its user-oriented services to UM community has enabled the development of another successful NSF-MRI grant application for the "Acquisition of an Advanced FTIR Imaging Microscope for Multi-disciplinary Research and Training in the State of Mississippi".

The images developed using the new microscope have been recognized by national and international organizations and won awards in the imaging contests organized by the Royal Microscopy Society, London, UK and JEOL, Inc., USA. These recognitions reiterate the capabilities of the SEM facility on par with other top-notch imaging facilities from around the world.

The project, with a no-cost extension, has ended 09/30/2021. However, the Microscopy and Imaging Center will continue to serve the UM community by providing high-quality imaging and training services to support the university's cutting-edge research and education programs.
